0: Image copyright AFP/Getty Images Image caption Most couples in Japan end up using the husband's surname NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Japanese Supreme Court has upheld a law that married couples must have the same surname, in a blow to women's rights activists. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Campaigners have said the law was discriminatory as most couples end up using the husband's surname. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR However, the court said the law did not violate the constitution, public broadcaster NHK reported. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It did, however, deem a separate law that stops women remarrying within six months of a divorce unconstitutional. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Both sets of laws date back to Japan's 19th Century Meiji era. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Surname row: What do other countries do? NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Judge Itsuro Terada noted that among the Japanese there was already informal use of maiden names, which eased the impact of the surname law. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said parliamentarians should decide on whether to pass new legislation on separate spousal names. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Japan Times cited studies in the past 40 years which show that more than 96% of Japanese couples opt for the husband's surname. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The surname case was brought by three individual women and one couple in a civil partnership, who argued that the law was unconstitutional, discriminatory and archaic. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Two lower courts have already ruled against them and public opinion on the questions was split. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Media caption Why some women in Japan are unhappy about their surnames NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Women in Japan were traditionally able to retain their maiden names after marriage, until 1898 when the law was enacted as part of a feudal family system where all women and children came under control of the male head of the household. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The system was abolished in 1948 - but the surname law has been retained. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Separately, a divorced woman had filed a legal challenge to a law that states women cannot remarry within six months of divorce. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The law was originally intended to help determine the paternity of a child born shortly after the divorce. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The Supreme Court agreed with her that it was unconstitutional, but in its ruling left room for the possibility of retaining the law with a shorter waiting period.
